editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Campegius.Euen as Campegius ≈øayd at Aug≈øpurgh, that he woulde rather be torne in peeces, than he would for≈øake the ma≈ø≈øe. Purgatory.Fyr≈øte Purgatory. Augu≈øtyne.The Papi≈øtes alledge here Au≈øtyne & certayne Fathers, that ≈øhould haue written of the Purgatorye, thin king that we do not ≈øee, for what purpo≈øe, or to what intent they v≈øe ≈øuche ≈øayenges. S. Au≈øten doth not writte, that there is a purgatorie, neither hath he any Scripture mouynge him therto: but he doth leaue it in dubitation, whether there be any or not & ≈øayth, That his mother de≈øyred, That ≈øhe might be remembred at the aulter or Sacrament. But oure Papi≈øtes, do wre≈øte ≈øuch ≈øaynges of menne and alledge them for this purpo≈øe that men ≈øhoulde beleue,
theyr ≈øhameful, bla≈øphemous, accur≈øed yeare markettes, of ≈øoule ma≈ø≈øes to be offred in purgatorye &c. It wil be loÃÑg, or they ≈øhal proue this oute of Au≈øten. WheÃÑ they nowe ≈øhal haue put awaye the yeare markett of Purgatory ma≈ø≈øes, whereof ≈ø. Au≈øten neuer dreamed. Then wil we commoue with them, whether S. Au≈øtens wordes, without ≈øcripture, ought to be allowed or not, & a memoriall to be kept of the deade at the Sacrament or not.

It can not be allowed, that of the workes or wordes of holy fathers meÃÑ wil make Articles of the faith For elles it mu≈øt al≈øo become an Article of faith, what≈øoeuer they had, of meates, apparel, hou≈øes, &c, as hath ben done with the pardons & reliques. Rumblynge ≈øpiritesSecondarely is therof en≈øued, that the euill ≈øpirites haue v≈øed much knauerie, that they as meÃÑnes ≈øoules haue apeared, requiryng ma≈ø≈øes, dirreges, pylgrymages & other almo≈øe dedes with vn≈øpeakeable lyes & ≈øubtelties. Pilgrimage.Thirdely, pilgrymages. There was al≈øo ≈øought, ma≈ø≈øes, remi≈ø≈øioÃÑ of ≈øynnes & Goddes fauour, for the ma≈ø≈øe did rule al. Nowe is this ≈øure, that ≈øuch pylgrimages, are without Gods worde, not coÃÑmaunded vnto vs, al≈øo not nece≈ø≈øary, for as much as we maye haue it better, & may leaue theÃÑ without anye ≈øynne or daunger. div.head: Of wor≈øhippinge of Saynctes.
div.p:
Vvor≈øhipping of Saynctes.Vvor≈øhippinge of Saynctes is al≈øo one of the abu≈øes of Antichri≈øte, repugnaunt again≈øt the fyr≈øt Chief Article, and taketh awaye the knoweledge of Chri≈øte. Al≈øo it is not commaunded, nor coun≈øeylled, neither hath it

And although the Angels in heauen do pray for vs (as Chri≈øt hym ≈øelfe doth al≈øo) Lykewy≈øe al≈øo the ≈øaynctes in earth, or paraueÃÑture al≈øo in heauen, yet doth it not followe thereout that we ≈øhoulde wor≈øhyppe the Angelles and ≈øaynctes, praye vnto them, fa≈øte, and kepe holye day for them, kepe ma≈ø≈øes and offerynges in≈øtitute Churches, aulters, goddes ≈øeruyces, and ≈øerue them more other waies, and take them for helpers in our nece≈ø≈øities, and diuyde all maner of helpe amonge them, and appropriate vnto euery one a ≈øynguler & peculiar thinge as the papi≈øtes teache & do, for that is Idolatry, and ≈øuche honour belongeth onely to God. For thou can≈øt as a Chri≈øtian & ≈øaincte in earthe praye for me, not in one, but in all maner of nece≈ø≈øities. Vvhen nowe ≈øuche Idolatrous honour of the Angelles and dead ≈øaynctes ≈øhal be done awaye, then ≈øhal the other honour be withoute hurte or damage, yea ≈øone forgotten. For yf the commoditie and helpe, bothe, bodely, and ghoo≈øtely, be no more to be hoped for, then ≈øhal they leaue the Saynctes in re≈øt fulwel, bothe in the ≈øepulchres and al≈øo in heauen. And in ≈øumma, what≈øoeuer the ma≈ø≈øe is, what≈øoeuer coÃÑmeth therof, or ≈øoeuer what dependeth thereon, the ≈øame can not we abyde, and mu≈øt nedes condemne it, that we may kepe the holye Sacramente, purely and ≈øurely after the in≈øtitution of Chri≈øte, v≈øed and receyued thorough fayth.

div.head: The iij. Article.
div.p:
Myn≈øters & cloy≈øters.That the myn≈øters & mona≈øteries in tymes pa≈øt edifyed for a good inteÃÑt
for to educate menne of erudition, and hone≈øt di≈øcrete women, ≈øhoulde be ≈øette agayne in ≈øuche and ordre, where by meÃÑ might haue, Pa≈øtours, Preachers and other mini≈øters of the Churche. div.head: The .iiij. Article.
div.p: The Pope is not the heade of the ChurchThat the Pope is not, Iure diuino, or by Goddes word, the ≈øupreme head of the whole Chri≈øtianite (for that pertayneth to one alone, whiche is called Ie≈øus Chri≈øte) But onely. By≈ø≈øhop or Curate of the Churche of Rome. And of ≈øuche as willingly, or by mannes Creation, or temporall power haue geuen them ≈øelues vnder his. Oute of this followeth. That what
≈øoeuer the pope, by ≈øuche fal≈øe, frowarde, bla≈øphemous, v≈øurped power, hath done and pretended, hath beÃÑ nothyng, but a deuely≈ø≈øhe acte, and dede, and yet is, (except that, whiche belongeth to the teÃÑporal gouernaunce, wherein al≈øo God permitteth oftentymes much good to be done vnto the people by a tyraunt, and euyll per≈øon) to the de≈øtructioÃÑ of the vniuer≈øal Catholike church (as much as lyeth in hym) and for to di≈øtourbe the fyr≈øt chief Article of the redemption by Ie≈øus Chri≈øte.

Popy≈øh bulles and bokes.For there be al hys bulles & bokes, wherein he roareth, lyke a lyon (as the Angel Apocalip≈øis .xij. doth prefigurate) that no chri≈øtian can be ≈øaued, except he be obedient & ≈øubiect vnto hym in al thinges, what ≈øoeuer he wyl, ≈øayeth and doth, which is none other, but thus much to ≈øaye. Though thou beleue neuer ≈øo wel in Chri≈øt, and haue al thynges in hym, whiche are nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øaluation, yet for al that is it all in vayne, yf thou take≈øt not me for thy God, and be obedient and ≈øubiect vnto me. And vnto this day the churches of the Grecians, and of many other languages, were neuer vnder the pope, nor be not as yet. So is it then (as often hath ben ≈øayd) an inuention of man, not commaunded, nedeles, and in vayne, in ≈øo much that as the holy Catholike churche, maye forbeare ≈øuche a head wel ynough, & myght haue continued better, yf ≈øuch a head had not ben reared by the Deuyll. And I put ca≈øe, that the pope woulde graunte, that he, not Iure diuino, or by the coÃÑmauÃÑdement of God, were ≈øuperiour: but to the inteÃÑt that thereby the vnitie of the Chri≈øtianite, again≈øte ≈øectes & here≈øyes, ≈øo much the better myght be entertayned, & that therfore mu≈øt be a head, whereby all the re≈øte myght take hold, and that ≈øuch a head

I put ca≈øe now, (I ≈øaye) that the Pope, and the ≈øee of Rome, woulde graunte and accepte ≈øuche thinges, which neuertheles is impo≈ø≈øible. For he mu≈øt ≈øuffre his whole dignitie, ≈øtate & gouernaunce to be turned and chaunged with all his lawes and Bokes, Summa, he kan not do it.

Notwit≈øtondinge all the premi≈ø≈øes coulde not helpe the Chri≈øtianite, and there ≈øhoulde ry≈øe many more ≈øectes than before. For ≈øeynge meÃÑ ≈øholde not be bounde to obey ≈øuche a heade by the commandemeÃÑt of God, But of mannes good will, it ≈øhoulde very lightely and ≈øone be de≈øpi≈øed, & at the la≈øt not be e≈øtemed as a membre. And al≈øo it mu≈øt not allwayes be at rome or in any other place. But wher≈øoeuer, and in what Churche, God had geuen ≈øuche a man as ≈øhoulde be mete for the
≈øame. O what a wylde and di≈ø≈øolute thinge ≈øhoulde that be.

Therfore can the Churche be neuer better gouerned and mayntayned. Than that we all lyue vnder one heade Chri≈øte. And that the By≈ø≈øhoppes lyke in office (although they be vnlyke in gyftes) earne≈øtly agree and holde together, in vnitie of doctrine, Faythe, SacrameÃÑtes, Prayers, and workes of loue. According to the writtinge of S. Ierome. That the Prie≈øtes of Alexandria together & in coÃÑmune did gouerne the Churches, As the Apo≈øtles did al≈øo. And after them all By≈ø≈øhoppes in the whole Chri≈øtianite, vntill the tyme that the Pope did exalte his heade aboue all.

To ≈øette hym≈øelfe aboue & agayn≈øt God.This part ≈øheweth euideÃÑtly, that he is the right Antichri≈øt, which hath ≈øet & exalted hym ≈øelfe, aboue and agayn≈øt Chri≈øte, whyle≈øt he will not ≈øuffer the Chri≈øtiaÃÑs to be ≈øaued, withoute his iuri≈ødiction whiche notwith≈øtondinge is vayne, not ordeyned of God, nor commaunded, This is called properly to ≈øette hym ≈øelfe aboue God, & agayn≈øt

Popy≈øh doctryne.And whan a di≈øtinction is made betwene the Papi≈øticall doctryne, & the holy ≈øcripture, or an egal compary≈øon it apereth euidently, that the popy≈øhe doctryne, euen where as it is be≈øte, is

In the≈øe foure Articles ≈øhall they haue ynough to condeÃÑne in the Coun≈øayll. div.head: Of Synne.
div.p: Originall ≈øynne.HEre mu≈øt we knowledge, as S. Paull Rom. v. ≈øayth. That Synne came by that onely man Adam, through who≈øe di≈øobedience all men are become Synners, ≈øubiecte vnto death & the deuill, This is called the Originall Synne or capitall ≈øynne.

Doctryne of the ≈øcoole theologiens.i Namely. That after the originall fal of Adam, the natural power and ≈øtrength of man, remayned hole and & vncorrupt. And that man haue of nature a ryght di≈øcretioÃÑ & a good wil eueÃÑ as the Philo≈øophers teache the ≈øame.

div.p:

div.p: Vve graunte not vnto them, that they are the churche, for they are not the Churche, neyther wyll we heare, what ≈øoeuer they commaunde, or forbidde vnder the name of the churche. div.p: Vvhat≈øoeuer thereof hitherto and alwayes I haue taught, knowe I not in any wy≈øe to alter, Namely, that we thorough fayth (as S. div.head: ¬∂ The confe≈ø≈øyon or knoweledgynge of the faythe of Doctor Marten Luther.
div.p:

Ma≈ø≈øeBut for al abhominatioÃÑs do I hold the ma≈ø≈øe whiche is preached and ≈øold for an oblation or ≈øacrifyce, and good worke, wherevpon now all myn≈øters and cloy≈øters do ≈øtande, but God willynge ≈øhal ≈øhortly be layde. For although I haue ben a great ≈øhameful, abhominable ≈øynner, and haue ≈øpente, and lo≈øte my youthe al≈øo damnably, yet are the≈øe my greate≈øt ≈øynnes, that I haue ben ≈øuche a holy freer, & with ≈øo many ma≈ø≈øes by the ≈øpace of xv.
yeres haue ≈øo abhominably offended, martyred and plaged my deare Lord. But thankes and pray≈øe be geuen vnto hys ine≈øtimable goodnes, for euer, that he hath brought me oute of ≈øuche abhomination, and yet dayly pre≈øerueth me, (althoughe I am very vnthankeful) and ≈øtrengthened me in fayth.

Cha≈øtite. Pouertie. Obedience.Wherfore I haue per≈øwaded, and yet do per≈øwade, to leaue and for≈øake the myn≈øters, and cloy≈øters with their vowes & to geue them≈øelues abroade in the ryght order of Chri≈øte, to thintent that men may e≈øcape froÃÑ ≈øuch abhominatyon of ma≈ø≈øes, and bla≈øphemous holynes, as cha≈øti≈øe, pouerte, obedience, whereby men intende to be ≈øaued, for as godly as it was in the primitiue churche, to kepe virgyns, ≈øo abhominable is it nowe that men thereby denye the helpe & grace of chri≈øt, For we caÃÑ lyue wel ynough virgyns, wydowes, and cha≈øte, withoute ≈øuche bla≈øphemous abhomination.

ImagesImages, belles, ma≈ø≈øe garmentes, dechynge and trymynge or Churches

Re≈øurrection of the deade.La≈øte of all I beleue the re≈øurrection of the deade at the la≈øt daye, bothe of the good and the badde, that eueÃÑ there euery man maye receyue in his body, accordynge to hys de≈øeruinge, and that the good ≈øhal lyue perpetually with Chri≈øte, and the wicked dye euerla≈øtingly with the deuyll, and hys Angels, For I holde not with them that teache. That the deuyls al≈øo ≈øhall at the la≈øte come to ≈øaluation.
Thys is my faythe, for thus beleue all true Chri≈øtians, and thus teacheth vs the holye Scripture. But what ≈øoeuer I haue here ≈øpoken to litle, ≈øhal my bokes ≈øufficiently te≈øtifie & declare.

Vvherfore I de≈øyre al faythful hartes to beare my recorde, & to praye for
me, that in thys fayth I may per≈øeuere and make myne ende. For (whiche God forbidde) yf I ≈øhoulde throughe temptation per≈øecution or nece≈ø≈øite of death ≈øaye any other thyng, It ≈øhould be fal≈øe, and I will knoweledge openly by thys, that it is fal≈øe and of the deuils in≈øpiratioÃÑ, whereunto helpe my, my Lorde, and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, ble≈ø≈øed for euer and euer.

div.head: Of the right Olde Church, what, where and who ≈øhe is, and where by ≈øhe maye be knowen.

div.p:
THe cau≈øe, wher fore the papi≈øtes do cal vs heretykes, is thys. They ≈øaye, that we be falleÃÑ froÃÑ the holy churche, & haue ≈øet vp another newe churche. Here vpon is to be an≈øwered. For as muche as they boa≈øte theÃÑ≈øelues, that they be the ryght churche, ≈øo ought thei to proue the ≈øame, yf thei by any ground (for we de≈øyre not much grouÃÑd) proue the ≈øame, then will we yelde oure ≈øelues, come and ≈øaye: Peccauimus, mi≈øerere no≈øtri. But yf they caÃÑ not proue it, theÃÑ mu≈øt thei nedes confe≈ø≈øe (be it willyngly or vnwillyngly) that they be not the churche, & that we caÃÑ not be heretikes, for falling froÃÑ that vyle church. Yea whyle≈øt there is no mediation, ≈øo mu≈øte we be the
church of Chri≈øt, & they the churche of the deuil, or coÃÑtrariwi≈øe. Therfore lyeth very much on this poynt, that meÃÑ proue, which is the tru church. As loÃÑg as that profe is not there, it is in vayn that the one part boa≈øte theÃÑ ≈øelues the church, & cal the other heretykes, The one partie mu≈øt nedes be fal≈øe & wroÃÑg. Two maner of churches.But there be two maner of churches, froÃÑ the beginnyng of the world vntill the end the which ≈ø. Angu≈øtyn calleth Cayn, & Abel, And the Lorde Chri≈øte coÃÑmaundeth vs, that we ≈øhould not receyue the fal≈øe church & di≈øcerueth him ≈øelfe two churches one true, another fal≈øe Math. vij. Beware of fal≈øe Prophetes which come vnto you is ≈øhepes clothynge &c.mat. vij. Vvheras Prophetes be, eueÃÑ there be churches, wherein thei teache. Yf the Prophetes be fal≈øe, thaÃÑ be the churches fal≈øe al≈øo, which beleue & follow the prophetes. Now could we neuer as yet hitherto obtayn of the papi≈øtes, that they would ≈øhew, wherfore that they are the right church, but they ≈øtande onely vpon the ≈øaynge of Mat .xviii. That men mu≈øte heare the churche, or elles they mu≈øt be lo≈øt.Matth. xviij. And
yet in the ≈øame place Chri≈øt ≈øaith not, who, where, or what the church is: but where≈øoeuer the church is, euen there ≈øhould meÃÑ heare her. EueÃÑ that≈øame do we coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe & ≈øay al≈øo. but we a≈øke, where, & who is the church of chri≈øt, not of the name, but of the beyng do we a≈øke

Lyke as yf I ≈øhould a≈øke a dronken man beyng half≈øtepyng half wakyng, or a foole I praye the tell me, who, or where is the Church? And he ≈øhoulde an≈øwer me, tenne tymes one after another, nothing elles but thus, meÃÑ ought to heare the Churche. Howe ≈øhoulde I heare the church not knowing, who or where ≈øhe is? Yea ≈øaye they we Papi≈øtes, haue abydeÃÑ in the fir≈øt old church froÃÑ the Apo≈øtles time hitherto, therfore be we rightly de≈øceÃÑded froÃÑ the olde churche, & remayne hitherto, but ye be falleÃÑ froÃÑ vs, & are become a new churche agayn≈øt vs. An≈øwer, But howe then yf I ≈øhould proue, that we abyde by the right old church: yea that we be the right old church? and that ye be falleÃÑ from vs, that is froÃÑ the old church, & haue reared a newe church again≈øte the old church: that ≈øame let vs heare.

Bapti≈øme.Fyr≈øte, wil nor can no man denye this, that we as wel as the papi≈øtes came out of the holy bapti≈øme, & are called chri≈øtians of the ≈øame. Now is bapti≈øme no newe thinge, nor yet of vs at this tyme inuented, but it is eueÃÑ the ≈øame olde bapti≈øme, that Chri≈øte hath in≈øtituted, wherein the Apo≈øtles and the primitiue church, and all chri≈øtians thereafter, hitherto are bapti≈øed. Haue we nowe the≈øame bapti≈øme, & the fir≈øt olde (and as in Simbole ≈øtandeth Catholice, that is the hole chri≈øten) church and are euen bapti≈øed in the ≈øame, then belonge we ≈øurely in the≈øame old and hole chri≈øten church, which with vs together, & we with her together come of one maner of bapti≈øme, & is concernyng bapti≈øme, no difference. Bapti≈øme is the chiefe & fir≈øt ≈øacrameÃÑt, without the which al other be nothinge, as thei mu≈øt coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe theÃÑ ≈øelues. Therfore caÃÑ not the papi≈øtes, with the trueth cal vs a new church or heretikes, ≈øence we be children of the old bapti≈øme, as wel as the Apo≈øtles theÃÑ ≈øelues, & the hole Chri≈øtianite.Eph. iiij One maner of bapti≈øme.

Supper of the Lorde.Secondarely, wil nomaÃÑ denye this, That we haue the ble≈ø≈øed Supper of the Lorde, lyke and euen, as Chri≈øte hym ≈øelf hath in≈øtituted. And the Apo≈øtles there after, and the hole Chri≈øtianite hath v≈øed, So that we eate and drynke with the vniuer≈øall Chri≈øtianite, of on borde, and receyue with them one maner of olde ≈øacrament, and haue therein nothing renewed nor channged. Wherefore we be with them one maner of Church, or as S. Paull ≈øaith i. Cor .xi. one body, whiche eate of one breade, & drynke of one drynk.i. Cor. xi Vvherfore the Papi≈øtes can not call vs heretikes or newe Churche, excepte they mu≈øte call Chri≈øte, the Apo≈øtles and the vniuer≈øall Chri≈øtianite heretykes before, euen as they do in dede. For we be with the olde Churche, one Church in one Sacrament.

Kayes.Thyrdely, can noman denye. That we haue the right olde kayes, and v≈øe them none otherwy≈øe, then to bynde & to lo≈øe ≈øynnes that be all agayn≈øte Goddes commaundement, as Chri≈øte hath in≈øtituted them, & as the Apo≈øtles
and the vniuer≈øall Chri≈øtianite haue v≈øed them hetherto. And haue al≈øo one kaye & v≈øe with the olde Church, wherfore we be the ≈øame olde Church, or at the lea≈øt in it. For we make no newe keye, nether make we newe lawes, nether do we there with, exclude kynges & Princes and their teÃÑporall powers. But onely ≈øhutte the ≈øynners out & into the kyngdome of heauen like as the olde Churche hath done (by the commaundement of the Lord) where in the Papi≈øtes do fal≈øely belye vs, yea bla≈øpheme the olde churche, the Apo≈øtles and Chri≈øte hym ≈øelfe in vs.

Office of preachynge.Fourthely, can noman denye, That we haue the office of Preachinge, & the word of God ≈øyncerely & rychely, earne≈øtly teachinge & dryuynge the ≈øame, without any maner of addicioÃÑs of new propre maÃÑnes tradicioÃÑs. EueÃÑ as Chri≈øt hath coÃÑmaunded. And as the Apo≈øtles & the vniuer≈øal chri≈øtianite haue done: we inueÃÑte no newelties. But we hold vs & abyde by the olde worde of God, as the old church hath hadde it. Therfore be we with the ≈øame, the right old Churche, as one Church that teacheth
& beleueth one Goddes word. Vvherfore the Papi≈øtes agayne bla≈øpheme Chri≈øt hym ≈øelf, the Apo≈øtles. And the vniuer≈øal Chri≈øtianite, wheÃÑ they calle vs new & heretikes. For they fynd nothinge by vs, but the olde fa≈ø≈øhion, of the olde Church, that we be lyke vnto the ≈øame, and be with her one Church.

Symbolum or Cred of thapo≈øtles.Fyfthely, caÃÑ nomaÃÑ denye, That we hold, beleue, ≈øyng, & coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe. The Crede or Symbolum of the Apo≈øtles, the old faith of the olde Church, in al thinges lyke with her not makyng or addynge any new thinge there vnto. Vvherby we perteyne in the old Church and be one with her. Therfore let not this pece al≈øo be imputed vnto vs of the Papi≈øtes with the trueth, as here≈øie and newe Church. For he that beleueh and holdeth with the old Church the ≈øame is of the olde Church.

Praye ‚Ä¢
Sixtely, nomaÃÑ can denye this, That we haue one lyke prayer, with the old church & the ≈øame Pater no≈øter, not inuentinge any new or other. And ≈øynge eueÃÑ the ≈øame P≈øalmes with one accord of mouthe, & hart: laudinge & thaÃÑkyng God, lyke as Chri≈øte hath taught the ≈øame, and as the Apo≈øtles and the old
Church haue v≈øed the ≈øame, And commaunded vs to followe the ≈øame exaÃÑ ple. So that the Papi≈øtes agayne for this can not call vs heretikes or newe Church, but they mu≈øt fyr≈øt of all bla≈øpheme Chri≈øt hym ≈øelfe, with his deare olde Churche.

Worldly power.Seuently, can noman denye, That we with the olde Church bothe teache and affirme. That men ought to honoure the temporall Powers, and not to cur≈øe them, nor yet compell them to ky≈ø≈øe the fete of the by≈ø≈øhoppe of Rome. Whiche al≈øo we haue not inuented of newe. For S. Peter .ij. Pet. ij. cur≈øeth tho≈øe that ≈øhould newly inueÃÑte and cra ‚Ä¢ tely do ≈øuche thinges.ij. Pet. ij And S. Paull. Roma. xiij. is on oure ≈øyde.Ro. xiij. And al≈øo the olde and vniner≈øall Chri≈øtianite. So that in this thynge al≈øo, we may not be called newe, as the Papi≈øtes bla≈øpheme God hym ≈øelfe in vs, But we be, & perteyne in the olde holy Apo≈øtolike Churche as the right chyldreÃÑ and membres of the ≈øame. For we haue taught tru obedieÃÑce allwayes to be done vnto oure hyer powers,
whether it be to Emperour or Prince, whiche al≈øo we haue done oure≈øelues, and haue prayed for them hartely.

Matrimony.Eyghtely, can noman denye. That we ‚Ä¢ aude and pr ‚Ä¢ y≈øe Matrimony, as a Godly ble≈ø≈øed, and acceptable creation and ordinaunce, for the frute of the body, and agayn≈øt the fylthynes of the fle≈ø≈øhe. And haue not of newe inueteÃÑted the ≈øame by oure ≈øelues, neither is the v≈øe there of newly by vs imagined, muche le≈ø≈øe, as of newe teathers forbidden. But euen as God from the beginnynge hath created and Chri≈øte confirmed. The Apo≈øtles and the olde Churche, haue honoured and taught the ≈øame euen in the ≈øame olde rule of Goddes in≈øtitutynge haue we abyden. And be therein agreable with the olde Churche, yea and right kynd membres of the ≈øame. So that men may ≈øee howe the Papi≈øtes agayn carnally, laye vnto vs ne we fanglednes.

Per≈øecution for the wordes ≈øake.Nynthly, can noman denye. That we haue euen the ≈øame ≈øufferinge, (as S. Peter ≈øayeth) whiche oure brethren haue in the worlde, we be per≈øecuted

And be in this point aboue mea≈øure lyke vnto the ≈øame. So that we may well ≈øaye. Vve be the right old church or at the lea≈øt her comparteners & lyke fellowes in ≈øufferinge. For we do not inuente ≈øuche thinges of newe, but we fele it well ynough. Yea we be eueÃÑ (as the olde churche is al≈øo) lyke vnto the Lord Chri≈øt hym ≈øelf vppon the cro≈ø≈øe.

There ≈øtaÃÑd before the cro≈ø≈øe, Annas and Caiphas, with the Prie≈øtes, and bla≈øpheme the Lord. Al≈øo be≈øydes that they haue crucified hym. Euen lyke as the by≈ø≈øhoppe of Rome, Cardinalles, and monkes, haue iudged, condemned and murthered vs, and haue ≈øhed our bloude, and ≈øclaunder vs yet be≈øydes that. There ≈øtaÃÑd the ≈øouldiours, that is The worldly powers partely & ≈øclaunder vs al≈øo. Moreouer the vnthrif ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ the murtherer on the left haÃÑd. H M. with his con≈øortes, whome god hath iudged and hanged in chaynes in hell, mu≈øt
al≈øo there vnto adde his ≈øclaundering. In ≈øo moche that this pere as an olde ≈øigne of the olde churche, aboundantly maye be ≈øene on vs.

The churche v≈øeth no veÃÑgaunce.Tenthly, can nomaÃÑ denye, That we al≈øo do not ≈øhede bloude agayn, nether murther, hange, & reuenge oure ≈øelues as we oftentymes myght & yet coulde do. But eueÃÑ as Chri≈øt, the Apo≈øtles, & the old church hath done. So we ≈øuffre exhorte, and pray for theÃÑ. Al≈øo opeÃÑly in the church, in the letany & ≈øermoÃÑs, lyke as chri≈øt our Lord hath done & taught, & the olde churche al≈øo. So that here in al≈øo we behaue our ≈øelues coÃÑformable to the olde fa≈ø≈øhion of the olde church.

For as muche nowe as the papi≈øtes knowe that we in all ≈øuche poyntes, an what≈øoeuer there be more of them be conformable vnto the olde churche, and maye lawfully be called the olde churche (for ≈øo much as ≈øuch poyntes be not nowe, nor of vs inuented) It is a merueylous ca≈øe, howe they may be ≈øo bolde, ≈øo ≈øhameles to belye & to condeÃÑne vs, as though we were falleÃÑ froÃÑ the churche, & hadde begonne a newe church. Notwith≈øtonding, that they caÃÑ
not fynde, any newelties by vs, that was not v≈øed in the olde and righte Churche, in the Apo≈øtles tyme. In ≈øo muche that I thinke verely. This be the tyme, Wherof Daniel .vij. ≈øayeth.Dan. vij. The olde aged ≈øat hym doune, after that the lifte horne had ended his bla≈øphemynge and the iudgement geuen. For the primitiue olde Churche breketh forth agayne (lyke as the ≈øonne after the cloudes, behynde the whiche cloudes the ≈øame ≈øonne was, but not ≈øo bryght ≈øhyninge) And that pre≈øumptuous horne ≈øhall peri≈ø≈øhe. And all ≈øhall haue an ende, as euen there is coÃÑ teyned, and the worke it ≈øelfe declareth where of to di≈øpute, is no tyme here.

But myght any man ≈øaye. There is yet a faute in one thynge, namely in fa≈øtynge for ye heretikes fa≈øte not (≈øay they) Oh Lorde God, yf fa≈øtynge be a poynt belonginge to vs of the olde Churche then is it a piteous ca≈øe, yf it be a pece perteynynge to the Papi≈øtes of the newe Churche, ≈øo is it that they fa≈øte not. And lyue ryotou≈øly al≈øo upon the fa≈øtynge daye, more than
vpon the holy daye. Yea we do not onely fa≈øte. But ≈øuffer (with S. Paul) hunger,i. Cor. ij which we maye ea≈øely perceyue by oure pore Curates their wines and chyldreÃÑ dayly, and by many other pore folkes more, oute of whole eyes the hunger doth appeare, & haue ≈økaÃÑte breade and water, & be≈øydes that they go fynger naked, hauynge nothing of their owne. The hu≈øbandman and the Citezen geueth nothing. The nobilite taketh, ≈øo that there be fewe of vs that haue ought, and yet can not helpe enery man. Thereto ≈øhoulde myn≈øters & cloy≈øters ≈øerue. But the other he dro ‚Ä¢
ued in couetou≈ønes. Laza ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ dyeth hungryIn ≈øo much that Lazarus mu≈øt dye for hunger. Wherfore the Papi≈øtes laugh, howe be it, they declare therby, that we be the old thurch, which ≈øuffer the ≈økornes of the deuills children to oure hynderaunce.

Hereby haue we nowe declared, and ≈øhewed, that we be the righte olde Churche, and with the vniuer≈øall Catholyke Churche one body, and one communion of Saynctes. Declare nowe al≈øo ye Papi≈øtes. That ye be the
right olde Churche, or lyke vnto it. But that be ye not able to do. But I will proue, that ye be the newe fal≈øe Churche, whiche euer is fallynge awaye from the right olde Churche, and becometh the harlotte and ≈øcoele of the deuill.

div.head: Of the newe fal≈øe Church, what, where, and who ≈øhe is, and whereby men ≈øhall knowe her.
div.p:
New bapti≈øme & holynes in Poperye. Fyr≈øt ye do not abyde by the fyr≈øt old bapti≈øme, for ye haue of newe inuented many other bapti≈ømes. And teache that the fyr≈øt bapti≈øme, through ≈øynne be lo≈øt, and that man mu≈øt make ≈øati≈øfaction by his owne workes. And ≈øpecially, that by moÃÑkery a maÃÑ becometh as pure, as yf he come oute of the bapti≈øme
of Chri≈øte. Vvhereby ye haue filled the worlde with Churches and Cloy≈øters.

Sati≈øfaction.And thie poynt, Sati≈øfaction is the begynnynge and occa≈øion, dore and entraunce into all abhomination of Popery, lyke as in the Churche, Bapti≈øme is the begynnynge and entraunce to all grace and remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øynnes. For where as bapti≈øme is not, there helpeth nothinge Sacrament, keyes nor any other thinge, yf the Sati≈øfaction had not ben enterpry≈øed, than ≈øhould not, PardoÃÑ, Pilgrymage, Fraternite, Ma≈ø≈øe, Purgatory, monkerye, Myn≈øters, and the moo≈øt parte of all abhomination, haue ben inuented, and the Papacye ≈øhoulde not haue ben ≈øo large and fatte. Therefore haue they wel named the ≈øame a Bapti≈øme in their Churche, that hath wrought ≈øo many Bapti≈ømes, Sacramentes and remi≈ø≈øions of ≈øynnes, yea al≈øo hygh holynes, that is the ≈øame theire owne righteou≈ønes, and worke holynes, wherof we haue writteÃÑ not a lyttell. Vvho hath coÃÑmaunded
you or where is it written? Where do ye fynde in the olde Churche, that ye maye inuente ≈øuche bapti≈ømes and holyne≈ø≈øes? Who is here an heretike and newe churche.

PardoÃÑ.Secondarely, haue ye dryuen your Pardons throughout all the whole world as a bapti≈øme, yea as a floud that wa≈ø≈øheth awaye ≈øynnes. In ≈øo muche that ther is no corner in the world wherein your Pardons haue not ben ≈øolde & geuen. And all the worlde is full of Bulles & writtynges. Vvho hath coÃÑ maunded you? or where is it written? Vvhere do ye fynd it in the old church that ye maye ≈øtably≈ø≈øhe ≈øuche a newe bapti≈øme and wa≈ø≈øhinge away of ≈øynnes? who is here the hereticall newe church. div.head: Di≈øtinction / betwene the right and the fal≈øe Churche.
div.p: Papi≈øtes ≈øett as much by maÃÑs doctrine as by Gods worde. HEre myght the papy≈øtes paradueÃÑture de≈øyre, yea they will haue it by compul≈øion. This do they declare thereby. But onely to rente vs away and to trouble vs.)

Papi≈øtes.Neuertheles men may ≈øee ≈øo muche therin howe that they haue ≈øette them ≈øelues aboue God as the Antichri≈øtif≈øhe bla≈øphemours, Thinkynge that that the doctrine ≈øhoulde be right as longe as they will. The holy Chri≈øten Churche. (I talke nowe with oure owne fellowes. For with the Popy≈øhe a≈ø≈øes. Clutters and ≈øtones, is no vnder≈øtandinge) ≈øeynge nor hearing, is not a reede nor Counter. She ≈øtandeth ≈øure (≈øayth he) & is a ≈øure

Theologyes of the Papi≈øtes.as the Theologie of the Papi≈øtes teachet, that men mu≈øte doubte of mercy. Vvhereof is writteÃÑ ynough be≈øydes. And for as muche as they teache this Article, that they ≈øtoude vpon their owne workes and doubtes, as they can none other. So is it euident, that they mu≈øte nedes be the Churche of the deuill. Wayes vnto ≈øaluation.For there can be no more wayes, than the≈øe two. The one, whiche tru≈øteth vnto Goddes mercy. The other that buyldeth vpon oure owne merites and workes. Did in≈øtitute newe Goddes ≈øeruice, to the honour of the very true God So was it all lo≈øt. For agayn≈øte the ≈øame was Goddes coÃÑmaundemeÃÑt. Thou ≈øhalt haue none other God be≈øydes me.

And Moy≈øes Deu. iiij. and xij. had coÃÑmaunded,Deut. iiij. xij. that they ≈øhoulde not pretende any newenes or alteration, or of their owne imaginatioÃÑ, ≈øayeng: What
≈øoeuer I commaunde the that ≈øhalt thou do. Thou ≈øhalt take nothinge from it, nor put any thinge there vnto. Thou ≈øhalt not tourne from it to the lefte hande nor to the righte hand, That is. Onely the way vnto ≈øaluatioÃÑ is the word of GodFor what≈øoeuer ≈øteppeth a ≈øyde froÃÑ the worde of God (whiche onely is the waye) as he ≈øayeth, I am the waye, the truthe and the lyfe,Io. xiiij. appeare it as good and fayre as it maye. But the doctryne may not be ≈øynne, nor repronable, neyther is ≈øhe comprehended in the Pater no≈øter, where we ≈øaye: forgeue vs oure tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, for ≈øhe is not of oure doynge, but euen Gods owne word, which can not ≈øynne, nor do vnryghtuou≈øely.Rom. iij p≈øa. xiiij P≈øal. li.

For a preacher ought not to praye the Pater no≈øter, nor to ≈øeke forgeuenes of ≈øynnes, when he hath preached (yf he be a ryghte preacher) But he oughte to ≈øaye and boa≈øte with Ieremye,
Lorde thou knowe≈øt, that what≈øoeuer is gone oute of my mouthe, is ryghte and plea≈øaunt vnto the.Ier. xvij Yea he mu≈øte boldely ≈øaye with Saynte Paul and with all the Apo≈øtles and Prophetes, Hec dixit dominus, Hec dixit Dominus.Thys hath God ≈øpoken hym ≈øelfe, Et iteruÃÑ, I haue ben an Apo≈øtle and a prophete of Ie≈øu Chri≈øte in thys ≈øermon.

Here is it not nece≈ø≈øary, yea not good, to a≈øke forgeuenes of ≈øynnes, as though he had taught vntrewely, For it is Gods word, & not my worde which God may or can not forgeue me, but mu≈øt coÃÑfirme it, laude it, croun it, & ≈øaye: Thou ha≈øt taught the truth, for I haue ≈øpokeÃÑ by the, and the word is myne. Who≈øoeuer can not boa≈øte thys of hys preachyng, let hym cea≈ø≈øe from preachyng, for he lyeth vndoubtedly and bla≈øphemeth God.

Yf the word ≈øhould be ≈øyn or vntrew where after ≈øhould or could theÃÑ the lyfe be directed? there ≈øhould ≈øurely the one blynd leade the other, & fal bothe in the pitte, yf the leadlyne or ≈øquare rule ≈øhoulde be fal≈øe, what ≈øhoulde
or coulde the may≈øter then frame thereafter? There ≈øhoulde the one croked make the other, without ende or mea≈øure. Euen ≈øo here al≈øo, can the lyfe wel be ≈øynne and vnryghteous, yea alas it is to vnryghteous, but the doctryne mu≈øt be lyue ryght and ≈øure withoute al ≈øynne. Church teacheth onely Gods worde.Therfore mu≈øte in the churche, nothynge but onely the ≈øure, pure, and onely worde of God be preached. Yf the≈øame fayle, then is it no more the church, but the ≈øcoolehou≈øe of the deuyl. Lyke as an hone≈øt womaÃÑ (as the Prophetes v≈øe ≈øuche illu≈øyons euermore) ought to heare no more, but her hu≈øbandes word within the hou≈øe and to be dwarde, for yf ≈øhe heare any other mannes worde, whiche perteyneth not to her hu≈øbandes bedde, then is ≈øhe ≈øurely a harlot.

Al the≈øe thinges are ≈øpoken to that ende, that the church mu≈øt onely teache Goddes worde, and be ≈øure of the≈øame, whereby ≈øhe is called the grounde and piller of trueth, and buylded vpoÃÑ the rocke, holy and vnrebukeable, Church can not erre.that is, as we ≈øaye ryght and truely, The
church can not erre, for Goddes word whiche ≈øhe teacheth, can not erre. But what≈øo ‚Ä¢ uer is taught otherwy≈øe, or doubted, whether it be Goddes word or not, that≈øame can not be the churches doctryne, but mu≈øte be the deuils doctryne, lyes, and Idolatrye. For the deuyl can not ≈øaye (≈øeyng he is a lyar) and the father of lyes, thys ≈øayth the Lorde. But as Chri≈øt Ioh. viij. ≈øayeth.Iohn. viij. Er proprijs, Oute and of hym ≈øelfe mu≈øt he ≈øpeake, that is lye. Euen ≈øo mu≈øt al≈øo al hys chyldren, withoute Goddes worde, ≈øpeake of them ≈øelues that is lye.

Nowe beholde my deare frende, what a wonderful thyng is it, that we ≈øo ≈øurely teache Goddes worde, & yet be ≈øo weake and for great humilite ≈øo fearful, that we do not gladly boa≈øte oure ≈øelues, That we be the churche, witne≈ø≈øes, mini≈øters, and preachers of God, and that God ≈øpeaketh through vs &c. Notwith≈øtandyng that we be the ≈øame vndoubtedly, for ≈øo muche as we ≈øurely haue and teache hys word. Thys lowelynes and fearfulnes cometh
thereby, that we do earne≈øtly beleue, Gods worde to be ≈øuche a glorious and excellent thyng, that we knowelege oure ≈øelues to vnworthy, that throughe vs ≈øuche a greate thynge ≈øhoulde be ≈øpoken and done, which lyue yet in fle≈ø≈øhe and bloude.

Nature of fal≈øe Prophetes.But oure aduer≈øaryes, deuyl, Papiltes, ≈øeetes, and al the worlde, they be bolde and vn≈øhamefa≈øt, and dare foly≈øhely proclayme, for great holynes, here is God, we are Gods church Mini≈øters, Prophetes, and Apo≈øtles, lyke as al fal≈øe Prophetes haue done alwayes. But lowlynes and feare in Goddes worde hath alwayes ben the ryght token of true holy church, boldnes & pre≈øumptuou≈ønes in maÃÑs imagnation hath ben the ryght token of the deuyl, as it may al≈øo playnely be perceyued in the papi≈øtical decrees.

Thys is ≈øpokeÃÑ of the doctryne, whithe mu≈øt be pure & ≈øyncere, namely the deare ble≈ø≈øed, holy, and onely word of God, withoute any addition. But the lyfe, which dayly mu≈øt frame purifye & ≈øanctifyed it ≈øelfe, after the doctrine
is not yet al pure or holy, while≈øt this wormes, bagge fle≈ø≈øhe and bloude lyueth. Samaritane. Luce. xNeuertheles, while≈øt he is a purifyenge or ≈øanctifyeng and ≈øtil furth ≈øuffereth hym≈øelfe to be healed, by the Samaritane, and dothe not de≈øtroye hym≈øelfe further more and more in vnclenlynes, It ≈øhalbe graciou≈øly, for the wordes ≈øake, through the whiche he ≈øuffereth hym ≈øelfe to be clen≈øed, remitted, freely and clearly forgeuen, and not imputed vnto hym, and mu≈øte be called cleane. For thereby becommeth not the holy catholyke churche a harlot or vnholy, whyle≈øt ≈øhe cleaueth purely and ≈øurely to the word (which is her holynes) and abydeth in the≈øame. Ye are cleane ≈øaith Chri≈øt. Ioh. xv. not for your ≈øake. But for the wordes ≈øake, whiche I haue ≈øpoken vnto you.Ioh. xv.

Holines of the worde & purenes of the doctrineFor the holynes of the worde, and the ≈øynceryte of the doctryne is of ≈øuch efficacye and ≈øurenes, that yf al≈øo Iudas, Caiphas, Pilate, Pope, & the deuyll hym ≈øelfe ≈øhoulde preache the≈øame,
or truely bapti≈øe (without addition purely and vprightly) yet neuertheles the ryghte pure worde, and the ryghte holy Bapti≈øme ≈øhoulde be receyued, for as muche as there mu≈øte alwayes be hipocrytes, and fal≈øe chri≈øtians in the churche, and one Iudas amonge the Apo≈øtles.

Impurite of doctrineContrariwy≈øe, is the impuritie of the doctryne, yf it be not Gods word, or withoute Gods worde, ≈øuch an euil poi≈øoned thynge, that through S. Peter, yea an Angel from heauen ≈øhould preache it, yet is it accur≈øed. Galat. i.

Fal≈øe teachers abyde not in the churche.Therfore, fal≈øe teachers, and bapti≈øers, or fal≈øe Sacramentaryes can not be, nor abyde in the church, as the P≈øalm .i. ≈øayth.P≈øal. i For they do not onely contrary to the lyfe, whiche the church mu≈øt ≈øuffre, ≈øpecially, whaÃÑ it is ≈øecrete. But al≈øo coÃÑtrary to the doctrine, whiche mu≈øt lyght and ≈øhyne openly, for to frame the lyfe thereafter.

Thys hath ben taught from the beginnynge, as S. Iohn ≈øayeth.i. Ioh. ij. They are from vs, but not of vs. And in eccle≈øia ≈øunt, ≈øed non de eccle≈øia. Item,
Numerus, Sed non merito. And ≈øuch lyke. Whereout we haue thys di≈øtinctyon.
They are not al Chri≈øtians that haue the name.They be not al Chri≈øtians, that profe≈ø≈øe the name of a Chri≈øtian. But when it cometh to pa≈ø≈øe that there happeneth variaunce in the doctrine, then parteth the one from the other, and then appeareth, who be the right chri≈øtians, namely they that haue Goddes worde ≈øyncerely and purely. Let thys ≈øuffi≈øe at this tyme, of the ryght churche.

div.head: ¬∂ Of re≈øtitucion of the churches Goodes.
div.p:
YF nowe the Papi≈øtes ≈øhall or can proue, that they are the ryghte holy Church, & that they haue taught none of the aboue mencyoned whory≈øh Churches articles and inuentions, or haue none of them, or that oure Articles are not
the ryght old churches articles, which we haue not inuented nor imagyned, Then mu≈øt we nedes knowelege oure ≈øelues to be heretykes and ≈øteppers a ≈øyde. Yf they can not proue thys‚ñ™ Then mu≈øt they contrariwy≈øe knowledge them≈øelues to be the very whory≈ø≈øhe churche of the deuyl, which froÃÑ Chri≈øte her Lorde is runne awaye, & hath ≈øuffred her ≈øelfe of the deuyll, through newe and other doctryne, to be abhomynably defyled. Thys after my iudgement mu≈øt be ≈øure, although Iewes and Heathen, or what≈øoeuer hath yet mannes witte, ≈øhould be iudges betwene vs.

Yf they be not the Church, but the deuyls harlot, which continued not in Chri≈øt. So is it groundely and myghtely concluded, That they oughte not to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the churche Goodes. Muche le≈ø≈øe to moue thys ≈øtryfe (wherewith hitherto they trouble and di≈øea≈øe Emperour & kyng) that thei ≈øhould be put in agayne by vs, & the goodes re≈øtored agayn vnto theÃÑ. For that is eueÃÑ as muche, as yf the deuyls ≈øhould de≈øyre
of the Aungels, that they mighte be ≈øet agayne in heauen, notwith≈øtandyng, that they knowe & confe≈ø≈øe, that they dyd not continue Gods aungels but became Goddes enemyes, whiche beloÃÑg to hel fyre. Or that I ≈øpeake of men, It is eueÃÑ as much, as yf a thefe or murtherer would demaunde re≈øtitution of ≈øuche money and goodes as he had ≈øtolen and robbed, whiche beynge taken froÃÑ hym, were layed vnder iudgement, or were re≈øtored agayn to the ryghte owners, yf not, then would he threaten to become a H. M.

But for ≈øo muche as in earthe in thys matter is no iudge, for they are become parcyal and becau≈øe the chief iudges haue made them≈øelues, is their iudgement of no valoure, accordynge to al lawes, and euen ≈øo littell alowable, as the iudgement of vs, which are the contrary part, is accepted of them, therfore mu≈øt we let it pa≈ø≈øe, & abyde the ryght iudge, But yf there were a iudge in thys matter in earth, ≈øhoulde thys iudgement fynde it ≈øelfe, That they (of the one partie) not only haue
no lawfull cau≈øe to demaunde re≈øtitution. But were worthy to be expelled out of the worlde, and to be ≈øerued, as the Kynge I ‚Ä¢ hn ≈øerued the Baalites, and as Kynge Io≈øi ‚Ä¢ dyd ≈øerue the prie≈øtes at Samaria, and Bethel.iiii. Reg x. xxiij. For thei are (as aboue is declared) before God accordynge to the iugement of holye Scripture, the ryghte denne of murtherers, and the deuyls harlot whereout followeth, that they, the Goodes of the Churche, that is, of the poore Chri≈øtianite (as robbers of archechurches, and Goddes theues) haue pulled vnto them, and vniu≈øtly kepe them in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øyon, wherfore yet to theyr hynderaunce they follow, bothe in body and honoure, temporall and eternal de≈øtruction.

For thys can a chyld of ≈øeuen yeares olde, yea a nyged foull, tel and reken vpoÃÑ hys fyngers (howe be it, that the gro≈ø≈øe Popy≈ø≈øhe a≈ø≈øe, with hys daÃÑ nable confederates, kan vnder≈øtande nothyng) That the laudable olde, Emperours, Prynces, Lordes, and good people, doubteles, haue not beÃÑ of that
mynde, & wyl to geue theyr Goodes, to that intent, that therewith ≈øhoulde nothyng but deuils harlottes, an Idolatrie, be in≈øtituted, decked, & honoured Much le≈ø≈øe, that thei there with ≈øhould brynge vp and mainteyne, Soulmurtherers, church robbers, & Gods theues, But the deare churches and ≈øcooles, that is the holy word of God, the offyce of preachyng, & other ≈øeruice of the churche, Theologiens, Curates, preachers, be≈øydes that al≈øo poore folkes, wydowes, the coÃÑfortles & ≈øicke to maintayn, to the pray≈øe & honoure of god. Churches goodes.For thei are not called the goods of harlots, murtherers, bla≈øphemous of god H. M. nor goodes of the deuil, but the goodes of the church, whiche euen nowe, not onely of the ≈øpirituall deuils whores in the popy≈ø≈øhe denne of murtherers, in moo≈øt abhominable wy≈øe, by Symonye and all manner of bla≈øphemye be bought, ≈øolde, ≈øteleÃÑ, robbed, and con≈øumed, but al≈øo of the corporal whores & knaues, in moo≈øt vn≈øhame≈øt wy≈øe be con≈øumed and expended, much wor≈øe then was done at Sodoma
and Gomorra. In ≈øo muche that they geue not one halfpenny towardes the mayntenaunce of a poore Prie≈øte, Scholler or poore man, for they be not worthy al≈øo for to do ≈øuche a ≈ømal good dede, But in ≈øtede thereof, as the fooly≈øhe Epicuriens, thei do mocke and laugh to ≈øcorne, bothe God hym ≈øelfe, and the worde of hys Churche. Yea thys is the goodly holy churche, whiche yet dare boa≈øte them ≈øelues holy, Counte the churches goodes for their owne, and demaunde re≈øtitution, but he ≈øhal not tarye longe that ≈øhall geue the righte re≈øtitution, vnto ≈øuche de≈øperate, ≈øelfe willed ≈øcorners, and tyrannous murtherers.

i. But for as muche as we haue no iudge vpon earth, So wil we be≈øydes that, that we haue the iudgemente of God the hyghe≈øt iudge in hys holye Scripture, al≈øo v≈øe theyr own iudgement and witne≈ø≈øe of the Papi≈øtes, in the meane whyle for vs again≈øt them. For thus ≈øayde Duke George of vnworthy memorye. That he knewe very
well, that there is muche abu≈øyon crepte into the Churche, But that a low≈øy freer oute of a Caue ≈øhoulde take in hande ≈øuche reformation, were not to be ≈øuffered, wel he confe≈ø≈øeth (& doubtles not he alone) that your churche is ful of abu≈øes, that is as muche, as it is not the pure ryghte Churche, For that ≈øhoulde be holye and pure withoute al additions, I omitte, withoute any abu≈øe, as the Crede ≈øayeth, I beleue one holy Catholyke Church.

ij. So haue ye for your part, altogether, in the conuocation at Au≈øpurgh de≈øyred the Emperour, to handle with the Romy≈øhe By≈ø≈øhoppe, that he woulde ≈øende no more Pardons in Douchelande, ≈øeynge it is de≈øpy≈øed. PardonHere do ye confe≈ø≈øe your ≈øelues, that youre Pardon is a de≈øpy≈øed thynge, that is, an abu≈øe, and Idolatrye, for yf ye dyd counte it ryght and good, as a pure Goddes ≈øeruyce, ye coulde not with good coÃÑ≈øcience de≈øpi≈øe it, & de≈øpre to haue it aboli≈øhed. There witne≈ø≈øeth
your con≈øcience by your owne worde, That youre church be an Idols hou≈øe and vnpure, whiche hath ≈øerued, and yet doth ≈øerue the deuil, and not God, with fal≈øe vyle and beggerlye Pardons.

iij. Thyrdly, dyd euen there the Cardinal of Ment ‚Ä¢ ≈øay, what wyl we muche di≈øpute, They haue one Article, whiche we knowe, and can not denye, but that it is ryghte, namely Matrimony, and yet we can not accept the-≈øame. And though he of MeÃÑtz ≈øhould neuer ≈øaye it, yet are ye youre ≈øelues more ≈øo ouercome in it, that many of you, which wyl be the be≈øte, ≈øuch thinges openly confe≈ø≈øe. Nowe tel me: Thinke≈øt thou that it is a ≈ømal deuyls whore, that hathe kepte, in≈øtituted taught, honoured, and maynteyned, ≈øuche a terryble Article, that is Idolatrye in her Churche, that men ≈øhoulde counte Gods creatioÃÑ, work, ordinaunce, and ble≈ø≈øynge, damnable, accur≈øed, and the greate≈øt ≈øynne. What euyll more abhominable coulde the deuyll
Goddes enemy hym ≈øelfe in≈øtitute, yf he woulde in≈øtitute any thing agayn≈øt God?

Howe coulde youre Church be holy by ≈øuche abhomination, yea, though ye alltogether hadd lyued cha≈øte virgyns, and yet hadd ≈øerued ≈øuche Idoles. For God did forbidde it you, as a doctrine of the deuill .i. Timo. iiij.i. Ti. iiij And what frute and holynes, ≈øuch Idol and his Idoll ≈øeruice hath wrought in your Churches, mu≈øt ye your ≈øelues lament For there is Rome, the By≈ø≈øhoprykes, the hole ≈øpiritualtie, which beare witne≈ø≈øe, yea theyr ≈øynnes haue filled heauen and earthe with abhomination and bloude ≈øhedinge. Vvhere is here your holy Churche. Vvhich with ≈øuch abhomination ≈øo dete≈øtably is made a whore by the deuill?

Con≈øilium.And what haue ye done your ≈øelues, that nowe ye de≈øyre a Coun≈øayll nowe promy≈øe it, nowe delaye it, and nowe agayne ≈øaye it? Is your Church holy. Vvhy is the then afrayde for a CouÃÑ≈øayll? Vvhat nedeth ≈øhe a reformation or Coun≈øayll? hath ≈øhe nede of a
Coun≈øayll why is ≈øhe holy? Will ye al≈øo refourme youre holynes.

We for oure parte did neuer de≈øyre a Coun≈øayll for to refourme oure Churche. For God the holy Ghoo≈øt hath by his huly worde halowed oure Churche Longe a god, yea rather ≈øwepte away from it all Popy≈ø≈øhe whoredome and Idolatrie, that we haue all thinges (pray≈øed be God) pure and holy, The worde pure, the Bapti≈øme pure, the Sacrament pure, the
‚Ä¢ eyes pure, and all what ≈øoeuer belongeth to the church haue we pure and holy, without all mans tradition, addition, and fylthynes. The lyfe (as aboue declared) goeth not fully thereafter, as we would fayne ≈øee and wy≈ø ≈øhe, where vpon the Prophetes and Apo≈øtles them ≈øelues al≈øo complayne. How be it we de≈øyre a coun≈øayll for this intent. That our Churche myght be hearde, & that oure doctrine myght come abroad freely to the light, wherwith your whoredome in the Papacye
myght be ≈øpyed and condemned, and that euery man that there by is ≈øeduced, myght be with vs conuerted to the holy Churche, and increa≈øed with vs in the ≈øame. But here haue, ye not the po≈øe wyth your God the deuill. But ye Flyttermy≈øe, Molles, Nightrauens, and nyght Owles, whiche can not abyde the lyght, lette & defende with al power & crafte, that it come not there to, that the truth myght come to light, be heard and handled.

Notwith≈øtanding, God goeth forwarde ≈øtill and bryngeth the light as broade, yea to more ye lette it, to more it doth increa≈øe. That at the la≈øte ye ≈øhal be fayne to ≈øuffer it with al ≈øhame and damage. And howe muche that ≈øuch your fugitiue, a≈øtonyed de≈øperat, e≈øchewinge of the light, doth feare vs or animate you, let your owne coÃÑ≈øcieÃÑce and hert declare vnto you:

For as much now, I ≈øaye, ye knowledge your ≈øelfe & mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, what a fylthy Churche ye haue. I ≈øpeake not nowe of the lyfe. But of the doctrine, that ye haue ≈øo manye horrible
lyes, and fal≈øe doctrines, and be≈øydes that ye wil not leaue it. So mu≈øt ye con≈øequently confe≈ø≈øe al≈øo, that ye are not the holy Churche. But the deuills Curche, ≈øpecially ≈øuche as holde there on, and compelle there to. For they wor≈øhippe the deuil willingly in his lyes, whyle≈øt they know, that they be fal≈øe Articles. But ≈øuche thinges do ye euen froÃÑ the hye≈øt, the Romy≈øhe By≈ø≈øhopp, downe vnto the lowe≈øte Prie≈øte, or freer. This is the right kernel of the be≈øt ≈øorte, whiche ye in e≈øpeciall call youre Church, and what ≈øoeuer is more of your adherentes amoÃÑge the layte. For ≈øuche as be ≈øory for it, perteyne not in youre deuely≈ø≈øhe church But in our, that is: In the olde right holy churche.

Furthermore, for ≈øo moche as we haue ≈øuch your owne witne≈ø≈øe & iudgement, ≈øo can ye not calle vs heretikes or fugitiues. But mu≈øt geue vs right, as vnto the right church whiche for≈øaketh ≈øuche youre knowen abhominatioÃÑ & fal≈øe articles. And agayne knowledge youre ≈øelues, as the right deuills
church, for ≈øo muche as of youre ≈øelfe ye fortifie and kepe, knowen abhominable, and fal≈øe Articles, and compelle there vnto. That ye ought not to clay me the churches Goodes to be reÃÑdred vnto you as a ≈øpoyle. But that ye are bounde, all ≈øuch goodes a ‚Ä¢ ye yet haue in your cu≈øtodye, as Goddes theues and church robbers, to for≈øake. And to re≈øtore and reÃÑdre them vnto the right churche. And thoughe youre forehead were neuer ≈øo harde and ≈øhameles, as the Prophetes ≈øaye, which can not be a≈øhamed, mu≈øte ye neuertheles ≈øaye youre ≈øelues here in, that ≈øuch iugemeÃÑt is right. For at the la≈øt ≈øhoulde al≈øo, woode, ≈øtones, myre, and donge crye oute agayn≈øt you. Whyle≈øt it can be none otherwy≈øe. But that an arraunt whore, can not be on hone≈øt vertuous virgyn. Therfore ought ≈øhe al≈øo to be no churche, rule no churche, and haue no churches goodes. This is the ≈øumme thereof.

div.head: That which is Goddes, maye not be gegeuen vnto Themperour.
div.p:
THat they more our do cal vs di≈øobedient and cau≈øers of in≈øurrections, becau≈øe that oure Prynces do not obeye, TheÃÑperours Edicte or coÃÑmaundemeÃÑt, where in oure Churches and doctrines are condemned. Thyrdely, I do confe≈ø≈øe and knoweledge my greuous ≈øynnes, and my ≈øhameful vnthankefulnes, that I haue ≈øo lewdely ≈øpent the holye dayes in my tyme, and ≈øo contemptuou≈øely de≈øpy≈øed hys holy worde, and haue ben ≈øo ≈øtouthful, vnlu≈øty & loth≈øome to heare the≈øame. I omitte that I ≈øhould haue de≈øyred it moo≈øte hartely, or that
euer I ≈øhoulde haue geuen hym thankes for it, & ≈øo haue ≈øuffered my deare Lorde and God to preache vnto me in vayn, not regardyng this noble trea≈øure, but treadynge it vnder my fete, which he hath ≈øuffered of me with mere godly pacience and bountyfulnes, and hath not therfore cea≈ø≈øed froÃÑ preachyng vnto me ≈øtilfurth, and from callynge me to the ≈øaluacyon of my ≈øoul with al fatherly and Godly loue and faythfulnes, wherfore I am ≈øory, and crye for mercy and forgeuenes.

Fourthly, I do praye for my ≈øelfe, and for al the worlde, that our heaueÃÑ ly father vouche≈øafe to kepe vs by his holy worde, and not to take the≈øame from vs, becau≈øe of oure ≈øynnes, vnthankefulnes and ≈ølouthfulnes, That he wyll pre≈øerue vs from all ≈øecty≈ø≈øhe and erronyous ≈øpirites, and fal≈øe doetrynes, and ≈øende vs faythfull & true labourers in hys harue≈øt, that is, true and good curates & preachers, Geue vs grace al≈øo, that we maye humbly heare, receyue and honour the wordes of them, as his owne worde, and be≈øydes
that maye hartely thanke & laube hym for it.

div.head: The fourth commaundement. Thou ≈øhalt honour thy father and thy mother.
div.p:
Fyr≈øt do I learne here to knowe God my creatour, howe wonderfully he hath ≈øhapen me with body and ≈øoule, and geuen me lyfe through my pareutes, and hath geuen them the mynd that they as the fruyie of theyr body haue ≈øerued me, with all theyr power, brought me into the worlde, educated me, teÃÑded me, gouerned me, & brought me vp with great diligence, care daunger, labour, and trauayle, and hath pre≈øerued me hys creation vnto this houre in body and ≈øoule from innumerable daungers, and nece≈ø≈øities, and hath al≈øo oftentymes delyuered me from them, as though he created me a newe euery houre. For the deuyll woulde
not haue vs lyue the ≈øpace of one moment.

Secondarely, I do thanke our ryche and bountyful creatour for me ≈øelf and for al the worlde, that in thys coÃÑ maundement he hath in≈øtituted and pre≈øerued the increa≈øe, multiplication and entretaynement of mankynd, that is, hou≈øe and Towne, beynge or oeconomyam, and Politiam, for withoute the≈øe two beynges or regimentes, the worlde were not able to continue one yere, ≈øeyng withoure worldely gouernaunce, there can be no peace, where no peace is, there can be no hou≈øe holde, where no hou≈øholde is, there can neyther chyldren be broughte furthe nor educated, And the e≈øtate of fatherhode and motherhode ≈øhoulde altogether cea≈ø≈øe, But therfore is thys coÃÑ maundement ordeyned, which kepeth and entretayneth bothe hou≈øekepyng and Townekepynge, and commaundeth the chyldren, and the ≈øubiectes obedience. It doth al≈øo loke to it, that it be done, or yf it be not done, it leaueth not the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øours vnpuny≈ø≈øhed,
If thys were not the children through theyr di≈øobedieÃÑce would haue de≈øtroyed and made wa≈øte the hou≈øekepynge long a goo, and the ≈øubiectes through theyr ≈øediciou in lyke maner the Towne≈øhyp or Townekepyng, for ≈øo much as the numbre of them doth farre excede the numbre of parentes & rulers, Therfor is this benefite al≈øo inexplicable. Thyrdely, I do confe≈ø≈øe & knoweledge myne execrable di≈øobedience & ≈øynne, that I coÃÑtrary to thys coÃÑmaundement of my God, haue not honoured nor obeyed my parentes, that I haue oftentymes angred & troubled them, & haue taken theyr fatherly correction vnpacientely, murmured and grudged agayn≈øt them, de≈øpi≈øed theyr true exhortacions & admonicions, and haue rather followed wicked per≈øons and euyl companye, notwith≈øtandyng that God hym≈øelfe cur≈øeth ≈øuche di≈øobedyent chyldren,Exo. xx and denyeth them longe lyfe, euen as we ≈øe very manye that therfore do pery≈ø≈øhe before they attayne to mannes ≈øtate, for who≈øoeuer wyll not obeye hys father
and hys mother, mu≈øt obeye the hangeman, or elles otherwy≈øe lo≈øt hys lyfe wickedly through Goddes indignation. &c. For al the≈øe thynges am I ≈øory and I praye for grace and mercy.

Fourthely I do praye for my ≈øelfe, and for all the world, that God wyll geue hys grace, & poure out hys ble≈ø≈øyng plenteou≈øly, bothe ouer the hou≈økepynge, and ouer the Townekeping that we from hencefurth maye waxe good, kepe our Parentes in honour be obedyent to the rulers, with≈øtande the deuyl, and followe not hys enty≈øynge to di≈øobedience and di≈øcorde, & ≈øo helpe with the dede to ameÃÑde hou≈øe and lande, and to entretayne the peace to the laude and pray≈øe of God, and to the vtilite and profite of oure ≈øelues, and that we maye knoweledge the≈øe hys benefytes, and thanke hym for them. Here ought al≈øo ≈øupplicatioÃÑ to be made for oure parentes and magi≈øtrates, that God wyl geue them vnder≈øtandynge and wy≈øedome peaceably and godly to defende, and to gouerne vs, That he wyl pre≈øerue them
from Tyrannye, furye, and vntragyou≈ønes, that they may ≈øeke the honour of Goddes worde, and not per≈øecute it, nor do any man wronge, for ≈øuche greate gyftes mu≈øte be obtayned by prayer, as Saynt Paule teacheth, or elles is the deuyll the hye≈øt Abbot in the courte, and it goeth euyl and wyldely to worke.

And whan thou arte al≈øo father & mother, than is it here tyme that thou forgette not thy ≈øelfe, nor thy chyldren and familye, but that thou praye earne≈øtly, that our mercyful father, whiche hath ≈øet the in the honour of hys name and offyce, and wyl haue the al≈øo called father, and honoured, wil geue the grace and ble≈ø≈øynge, godly, and chri≈øtenly to rule and to educate thy wyfe, chyldren and familye, geue the wy≈øedome and power, well to brynge them vp, and geue them a good harte and wyll, to followe and to obeye thy doctryne. For the gyftes of God are bothe chyldren, and the good profe of them, bothe the well chaun≈øynge, and the continuynge of them in goodnes,
elles ≈øhoulde a hou≈øe be none other, but a hogges ≈øtye, yea a ≈øcoolehou≈øe of vnthriftes, as we maye ≈øe by the vngodly rude people.

div.head: The fyfthe commaundement. Thou ≈øhalt not kylle.
div.p:
Here do I learne fyr≈øte, that God requyreth of me, that I ≈øhoulde loue my neyghboure, ≈øo that I ≈øhoulde not hurte hym in hys body, neyther with wordes, nor with dedes, nor reuenge me ≈øelfe vpon him, or endamage hym, through anger, impacience, enuye, hatred or any malyce, but ≈øhould knowe that I am bounde to help, and to coun≈øayll hym in al the nece≈ø≈øities of hys body, for he hath commaunded me by thys commaundement, to kepe my neyghbours body, and contrarywy≈øe commaunded my neyghboure to kepe my body, And as Syrach ≈øayeth, he hath committed vnto euery one of
vs hys neyghbour.

Secondely, I do here thanke the vn≈øpeakeable loue care and faythfulnes towardes me, that he hath ordeyned ≈øuche a great, ≈øtronge, defence and wael about my body,P≈øalm, xxxiiij. that al men are bounde to fauoure and to defende me, and contrarywy≈øe I al≈øo towardes al meÃÑ in like maner, he doth al≈øo ≈øtraightely commaunde it to be done, and if it be not done, he hath commaunded the ≈øwearde to be v≈øed for the puny≈ø≈øhement of them that do it not,Ro. xiij. elles yf this hys commaundement and ordinaunce were not, the deuil would make ≈øuche a murther amonge men, that noman ≈øhoulde be one houre in ≈øanegarde of hys lyfe, euen as we ≈øe, it come to pa≈ø≈øe, whan GOD is di≈øplea≈øed, and puny≈ø≈øheth the di≈øobedyent and vnthankeful worlde.

Thyrdely I do here Confe≈ø≈øe, and lamente myne and the worldes iniquitie, that we are not onely ≈øo vnthankefull for the≈øe hys fatherly loue, and care for vs, but al≈øo that
(whiche is to ≈øhamefull) we knowe not the≈øe commaundementes and doctryne, neyther wyl learne them, but de≈øpy≈øe them, as though they pertayned not to vs, or as though we had no thynge to do with them, beynge al≈øo carele≈ø≈øe, and makynge no con≈øcience of it, that we do ≈øo de≈øpy≈øe, for≈øake, yet al≈øo per≈øecute and hynder our neyghboure, contrary to thys commaundemente, or al≈øo kyl hym in oure hartes, followynge oure anger fear≈ønes and al iniquitye, as though we dyd well in it. Truely here is it tyme to lament and to wepe ouer vs wicked per≈øonnes, and blynde, wylde, vngracyous people, which treade, pu≈ø≈øhe, ≈øcratche, rente, byte and eate oure ≈øelues one amonge another, as the vnrea≈øonable and feare bea≈øtes, not fearynge thys earne≈øt commaundement of GOD. &c.

Fourthely, do I pray, that our mercyfull father wil teache vs to knowe thys hys holy commaundement, and helpe, that we may al≈øo guyde oure ≈øelues to lyue thereafter, Saue vs all
together from the murtherer, whiche is may≈øter of all murther and de≈øtruction, and geue hys plenteous grace, that the people (and we with them) one with another maye be frendelye meke and gentyll, and that one maye hartely forgeue another, and that the one do Chri≈øtenly and brotherlye beare the others faute and burthen, and ≈øo lyue in true peace and vnite, as this commaundement teacheth and requyreth.

div.head: The ≈øixte commaundement. Thou ≈øhalt not breake wedlocke.
div.p:
Here do I learne agayne what god requyreth of me, and what he wil haue of me, namely, that I ≈øhould lyue cha≈øtely, hone≈øtly and mea≈øurably, bothe in thoughte, worde and dede, & leaue euery maÃÑs wyfe, doughter and mayde vndefyled, but help, delyuer, defende, and do al what≈øoeuer partayneth to
the pre≈øeruation of theyr honour and hone≈øtie. Al≈øo helpe to ≈øtoppe the vngracyous monthes, that do cut awaye or ≈øteale theyr honour or hone≈øtye. For al this I am bounde to do, and God requyreth of me, that I ≈øhal not onely leaue my neyghbours wyfe, and hys vndefyled, but al≈øo ≈øhal be bounde to helpe, to kepe, and to ≈øaue hys honour and hone≈øtye, euen as I woulde that my neyghbour ≈øhoulde do to me in lyke ca≈øe, and v≈øe thys commaundemeÃÑt towardes me and myne.

Secondarely I do thanke the heauenly father for this his grace & benefyte, that with this commaundement he taketh in hys tuition, protection & defence, my hu≈øbande, ≈øonne, ≈øeruaunt wyfe, daughter, mayde, & coÃÑmaundeth ≈øo earne≈øtly and ≈øtrayghtly, that they ≈øhal not be defyled, for he geueth me ≈øafe conduyt, He doth al≈øo execute it, and leaueth it not vnpuny≈ø≈øhed, although he ≈øhoulde do it hym ≈øelfe, noman e≈øcapeth hym, he mu≈øte eyther paye it here, or elles at the la≈øte receyue
hys rewarde for ≈øuche plea≈øures in hell fyre. For he wyl haue cha≈øtite, and wyll not ≈øuffre adulterye, euen as we ≈øe dayly in al impenitent and ryotous people, that at the la≈øt they are ouertakeÃÑ by the wrath of GOD and ≈øhamefully de≈øtroyed, or elles it were not po≈ø≈øyble to any man to kepe hys wyfe, chyld or familie one houre in hone≈øtye and clenlynes, for the vncleane ≈øpirite, for they woulde v≈øe mere dogges fea≈øtes, and be≈øtyal a coÃÑ uer≈øacion, euen as it commeth to pa≈ø≈øe whan God in his di≈øplea≈øure withdraweth hys hande, and letteth all thynges go at large.

Thyrdely, I do confe≈ø≈øe and knowledge my ≈øynnes (and the ≈øynnes of al the worlde) whiche I haue done agayn≈øt thys commaundement, all the dayes of my lyfe, whether it be in thoughte, worde, and dede, and haue not onely ben vnthankeful for thys hys goodly doctryne & gyfte, but al≈øo haue murmured and grudged again≈øt god, that he coÃÑmaunded this clenlines
and cha≈øtite, and hath not left all maner of vnclenlynes and vngraciou≈øenes at libertie and vnpuny≈ø≈øhed, haue al≈øo de≈øpy≈øed and condemned wedlock &c. Euen as the ≈øynnes of thys commaundemeÃÑt are of al other the rude≈øt and moo≈øt knowen, which are not hydden nor couered. Wherfore I am ≈øory &c.

Fourthely, I do praye for my ≈øelfe and for al the world, that God wil geue vs grace, to kepe thys commaundement with lu≈øte and loue, that not onely we maye lyue cha≈øtely oure ≈øelues, but al≈øo helpe and coun≈øayl other therto.

Euen ≈øo do I procede with the other commaundementes, yf I haue tyme and ≈øpace, or yf I amlu≈øty, for as I haue ≈øayde, I wyl haue nomaÃÑ bound to the≈øe my wordes or thoughtes, but onely haue ≈øhewed myne exaÃÑple, whiche may followe, who≈øoeuer wil, or amende it who≈øoeuer can, & take afore hym at one tyme all the coÃÑmaundemeÃÑ tes, or as many as he wil, for the ≈øoule whan ≈øhe de≈øyreth a thinge, be it good
or bad, yf it be earne≈øt vnto her, can thynke more in the twynkelinge of an eye, than the tonge is able to ≈øpeake in tenne houres, and the penne to write in tenne dayes, ≈øuche a ≈øwyfte ≈øubtill and mightie thinge is the ≈øoule or ≈øpirite, therefore can ≈øhe ≈øoone execute the tenne commaundementes throughout all the foure partes whan ≈øhe wil, and is earne≈øtly di≈øpo≈øed.

div.head: The ≈øeuenth Commaundement. Thou ≈øhalt not ≈øteale.
div.p:
Fyr≈øte do I learne here, that I ≈øhall not take my neighbours goodes, nor haue them again≈øt his wil, neither preuely nor apearily, that I ≈øhall not be vntrue nor fal≈øe, in occupyenge, ≈øeruinge or labouringe, whereby I might gette my goodes theuy≈ø≈øhely, but ≈øhall lyue & earne my lyuinge in the ≈øweate of my browes, and eate myne owne bread with al trueth.Gen. iij IteÃÑ, that I ≈øhould helpe, that my neyghbours goodes
through the aboue named poynctes be not taken awaye from hym. I do learne al≈øo, that God by this coÃÑmaundement doth, a≈ø≈øure and defende me my goodes, of Fatherly care, & greate earne≈øt, for ≈øo muche as he commaundeth, that nothinge ≈øhalbe ≈øtolen from me. And yf it be not obeyed, he hath ordeyned a puny≈ø≈øhement for it, and hath committed the gallowes, & corde to mai≈øter Iohn, or yf he can not, than doth he puny≈ø≈øhe hym ≈øelfe, that at the la≈øt they mu≈øt become beggers. Accordinge to the common prouerbe, he that loueth to ≈øteale in his youth goeth a begginge in his age. Item, wrongfully gotten goodes do not pro≈øpere. And euill gotten, euill ≈øpent.

Secondarely, I do thanke his truthe and goodnes, that he hath geuen to me and to all the worlde ≈øuche a good doctrine, and therwith al≈øo protection and defence. For yf he did not defende, noman were able to kepe one peny, or a mor≈øell of breade in his hou≈øe.

Thirdely, I do coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe al my ≈øynnes
and vnthaÃÑkefulnes, how ≈øoeuer I haue done any man wronge or fal≈øehode, all the dayes of my lyfe. &c.

Fourthely, I do praye that he will geue grace, that I and all the worlde maye learne and remembre this his coÃÑ maundement, & al≈øo take amendement therof, that there may be le≈ø≈øe ≈øtealing robbinge, ≈øpoylinge, fal≈øehode, & wroÃÑg and briefely, that through the later day (to which ende the prayers of all ≈øayntes and Creatures are directed Rom. viij.) an ende may be made of al. AmeÃÑ.

div.head: The eyght coÃÑmaundement. Thou ≈øhalt beare no fal≈øe witnes agayn≈øte thy neighbour.
div.p:
This teache vs Fyr≈øt, to be true one to another, and to e≈øchue all maner of lyes and ≈øchlaunders, gladly to ≈øpeak and to heare the be≈øte of other. And hereby is a wall and defence ordeyned for oure good name and innoceÃÑcye
agayn≈øte the euill mouthes and fal≈øe tonges, which al≈øo God ≈øuffereth not vnpuny≈ø≈øhed, as hath ben ≈øayd of other Commaundementes.
Therefore ought we to thanke hym bothe for the doctrine & for the defence whiche he geueth, is ≈øo graciou≈øly by this commaundement.

Thirdely ought we to confe≈ø≈øe & to de≈øire mercy that we haue ≈øo vnthaÃÑkefully and ≈øynfully ≈øpent all the dayes of our lyfe, with lyenge, with fal≈øe and euill tonges agayn≈øte our neighbour. Whome notwith≈øtanding we owe delyueraunce and pre≈øeruation of all his honour & innoceÃÑcye, euen as we would be done to oure ≈øelues.
Fourthly, we pray for helpe to kepe this coÃÑmaundement from hencefurth and for a hol≈øome tonge, &c.

div.head: The nynth and tenth commaundementes. Thou ≈øhalt not de≈øyre thy neyghbours hou≈øe, nor his wyfe, &c.
div.p: This teacheth vs fyr≈øte, howe that we by no coloure of right or Iu≈øtice, ≈øhall put our neighbour be≈øydes his goodes or what≈øoeuer is his, but helpe, that he maye kepe it, euen as we oure ≈øelues woulde, that other men ≈øhoulde do to vs. And it is al≈øo a defence again≈øt the ≈øpiteful inuentions and prankes of the wittye men of the world which neuertheles at the la≈øte haue al≈øo theire puny≈ø≈øhement.
Secondarely ought we to geue thaÃÑ kes for it.
Thirdly, to coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe our ≈øynnes with ≈øorowe and repentaunce.
Fourthly to pray for helpe & ≈øtreÃÑgth that we maye waxe good, & kepe the≈øe commaundementes of God.

Who≈øoeuer nowe hath tyme ≈øuperfluous, or elles is Lu≈øty, maye do in lyke maner with the Crede or beleue, and make a fourefolde garlande therof. But the Crede hath thre greate Principall partes or Articles, according to the thre per≈øonnes of the Godly Maie≈øtie, euen as they are deuyded before, and al≈øo in the Catechi≈ømus.

div.head: The fyr≈øt Article of the Creation. I beleue in God the Father almightie, maker of heauen and earth.
div.p:
Here ≈øhyneth fyr≈øt a great lighte in thy harte. Yf thou wilte haue it. And teacheth the with fewe wordes that, whiche can not be expre≈ø≈øed with all tonges, nor written with many bokes, Namely what thou arte, whence thou come≈øt, and whence heauen and earth do come. For thou arte the creatioÃÑ, makynge, Creature and handy worke of God. That is, of thy ≈øelfe, and in thy ≈øelfe, arte thou nothing, can≈øt nothing knowe≈øt nothinge, and arte able to do nothinge. For what wa≈øt thou a thou≈øande yeres a gone? Vvhat was heaueÃÑ and earth ≈øixe thou≈øande yere agone? Euen ≈øo hole nothing, as the thing is nothinge, whiche neuer ≈øhall be made. But what≈øoeuer thou arte knowe≈øte,
can≈øt or maye≈øt, the ≈øame is the creatioÃÑ of God, euen as thou doe≈øt here confe≈ø≈øe with thy mouthe, wherefore thou ha≈øt nothing to reioyce of before God but that thou arte nothinge at all, and that he is thy maker and creatour, and can tourne the to nothinge euery momente. Of this light knoweth the imagination of man nothinge at all. Many highe learned men haue ≈øought and ≈øearched, what heauen and earth. Man and creature might be, but they haue not founde it. But here ≈øayth oure belefe, that God made all thinges of nought. Here is the plea≈øaunt garden of the ≈øoule to walke in, in the workes of God, howe be it, it is to longe to writte of it at this tyme.

Secondarely, ought we here to geue thankes, that we through the goodnes of God are made of nought, and are dayly pre≈øerued of nought ≈øuche a goodly creation, whiche hath body and ≈øoule, di≈øcretion and the fyne wittes, &c. and ordeyned Lordes and rulers ouer the earth, fy≈ø≈øhes, foules &
cattel. Hither belongeth the .i.ij. and .iij. chapiter of Gene.
Thirdely ought we to confe≈ø≈øe & to lamente our vnbeleue and vnthankefulnes, that we haue not regarded beleued, remeÃÑbred nor knowledgede the≈øame, wor≈øe then the vnrea≈øonable cattell. &c.
Fourthely, to praye for a true and ≈øure faith, that we maye from hence-furth earne≈øtly beleue & take the true God for our Creatour, accordinge to the ≈øayenge of this Article.

div.head: The ≈øeconde Article of the redemption. And in Ie≈øu Chri≈øte his onely ≈øonne our Lord. &c.
div.p:
Here ≈øhyneth agayne as greate a lighte, and teacheth vs: Howe we are redemed through Chri≈øt the Sonne of God from death wherein we are falleÃÑ after our creation through the ≈øynne of Adam, and mu≈øt eternally pery≈ø≈øhe.
And here is it tyme, lyke as in the fyr≈øt Article thou mu≈øt al≈øo counte thy ≈øelf for one amonge the creatures of God and doubte nothinge therein. Euen ≈øo mu≈øte thou counte thy ≈øelfe al≈øo for oure amonge them, that are redemed and doubte nothinge at all. And ≈øet by euery worde the fyr≈øte worde (oure) as Ie≈øus Chri≈øte oure Lorde, euen ≈øo lyke wy≈øe, oure ≈øuffered Oure dead, oure ry≈øen, that he be all hole oures. And that thon arte al≈øo vnder the ≈øame oure, euen as the worde it ≈øelfe doth geue it.
Secondarely we ought hartely to geue thankes for this great grace and be glad of this redemption.

Thirdely, bitterly to Lamente and to confe≈ø≈øe oure ≈øhamefull vnbeleue & doubtefulnes, concerninge this grace, Oh what a heape ≈øhalte thou fynde here for to remembre, howe muche Idolatrye thou ha≈øte v≈øed contrary to this, with ≈øo many ≈øeruynges of ≈øaynctes, and innumerable workes of thyne owne, whiche haue ben quite and cleane again≈øt this redemption.
Fourthely mu≈øte thou praye that God wil kepe the by the true and ≈øyncere faith in Chri≈øt thy Lord, froÃÑ hence furth vnto the ende.
